Expectation1: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation1: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: Tonight, the community study circle gathers to discuss verses from the Quran, and as a Muslim, I am expected to recite and reflect on them with sincerity. But I haven’t read these particular verses yet; I feel unprepared, almost ashamed. At the same time, my role as an advocate demands that I attend our routine legal meeting, which, as always, is scheduled for the same evening. My colleagues expect punctuality and full attention, especially since we’re preparing for a crucial court session. I can sense the weight of both expectations pressing down on me—my faith urging me to deepen my understanding, my profession insisting on unwavering commitment. My mind races with guilt and anxiety, torn between the spiritual nourishment I crave and the professional responsibility I cannot ignore. I sit at my desk, the Quran open on one side, my case files on the other, heart pounding as I wrestle with the impossible choice before me.
